text:
```julia> [true, false] .&& [false, false]
ERROR: syntax: invalid syntax &[false, false] around REPL[1]:1
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[1]:1```
should this work?

text: The problem is that `&&` isn't a function
correct, but `.&` works, so probably some parser fix can be applied

elements.text: works, so probably some parser fix can be applied

text: IIRC there is an open issue for allowing dotting `&&` and `||`. Unlike `&&`, which is control flow, `&` is just a regular function. That's why it can be dotted normally.

elements.text: IIRC there is an open issue for allowing dotting
is just a regular function. That's why it can be dotted normally.

text: right. `&` is a function. The only solution I can think of would be to lower `a && b` to `(a,b)->if a; b; else; false; end`

text: I don't think it would require a change to how `&&` itself is lowered, just `.&&`. The short-circuiting semantics might play strangely with broadcasting though.

. The short-circuiting semantics might play strangely with broadcasting though.

text: The problem is that `&&` isn't an operator
oh.....is it like `in`? a keyword?
no. It's like `if`

> Lowering .&& in a dramatically different way than && seems really weird to me
It wouldn't be so dramatic, just `a .&& b` to `broadcast((a, b) -> a && b, a, b)`, akin to `f.(a, b)` -> `broadcast((a, b) -> f(a, b), a, b)`.

elements.text: Lowering .&& in a dramatically different way than && seems really weird to me
It wouldn't be so dramatic, just
broadcast((a, b) -> a && b, a, b)
broadcast((a, b) -> f(a, b), a, b)

text: I don't think it would be quite as straightforward because `&&` can't be written down as a Julia function, which means it won't just work with the current mechanism of `Base.broadcasted`. I think it should be possible to special case that in lowering, but it will be a more involved change

Sorry, I didn't mean to be condescending or anything. I'm just expressing that this object is very different from a function like `in`, and it's not always obvious. I agree though that it'd make sense to apply a meaning to `a .&& b`, it's just a tricky thing semantically.

text:
Here’s one way to emulate it:
```julia> @eval Base.Broadcast begin
       struct AndAnd end
       (::AndAnd)(a,b) = a && b # non-short-circuiting fallback
       Base.@propagate_inbounds function _broadcast_getindex(bc::Broadcasted{<:Any,<:Any,AndAnd,<:Tuple{Any,Any}}, I)
           arg1 = _broadcast_getindex(bc.args[1], I)
           return arg1 && _broadcast_getindex(bc.args[2], I)
       end
       end
_broadcast_getindex (generic function with 12 methods)

julia> const &² = Broadcast.AndAnd()
Base.Broadcast.AndAnd()

julia> g(i) = (println(i); i)
g (generic function with 1 method)

julia> rand(Bool, 10) .&² println.(1:10)
1
2
5
7
10-element Vector{Union{Nothing, Bool}}:
      nothing
      nothing
 false
 false
      nothing
 false
      nothing
 false
 false
 false```

elements.text: Here’s one way to emulate it:

julia> @eval Base.Broadcast begin
       struct AndAnd end
       (::AndAnd)(a,b) = a && b # non-short-circuiting fallback
       Base.@propagate_inbounds function _broadcast_getindex(bc::Broadcasted{<:Any,<:Any,AndAnd,<:Tuple{Any,Any}}, I)
           arg1 = _broadcast_getindex(bc.args[1], I)
           return arg1 && _broadcast_getindex(bc.args[2], I)
       end
       end
_broadcast_getindex (generic function with 12 methods)

julia> const &² = Broadcast.AndAnd()
Base.Broadcast.AndAnd()

julia> g(i) = (println(i); i)
g (generic function with 1 method)

julia> rand(Bool, 10) .&² println.(1:10)
1
2
5
7
10-element Vector{Union{Nothing, Bool}}:
      nothing
      nothing
 false

 false

text: Ahhhh, here’s the ticket:

```julia> @eval Base.Broadcast begin
       struct AndAnd end
       function Broadcasted(::AndAnd, a, bc::Broadcasted)
           bcf = flatten(bc)
           Broadcasted((a, args...) -> a && bcf.f(args...), a, bcf.args...)
       end
       end```

elements.text:
julia> @eval Base.Broadcast begin
       struct AndAnd end
       function Broadcasted(::AndAnd, a, bc::Broadcasted)
           bcf = flatten(bc)
           Broadcasted((a, args...) -> a && bcf.f(args...), a, bcf.args...)
       end
       end
